title: The Common People of Modern China
requirements: For postgraduate students under Division of History and undergraduate History Major & Minor students
description: This course is designed to explore the concept, the image and the livelihood of the “common people” from the last decades of the Qing dynasty to the 1940s. This era saw great changes of social and political theory: a ritual life that had reached from emperor into villages came to be articulated in relation to a central government and its cities. The rural population ceased to be central to ritual life and came to be marginalized. Orthodox values came to be looked upon as superstition. Meanwhile, a social ethos came to represent the fashion of a new age, and city life was looked upon as a symbol of progress. This transition from old to new repositioned the individual, family, nation, and even language and gender. This transition has continued to the present day, making us as much its creator as well as its product. This course seeks to raise questions about the society which we take for granted and in which we are now placed has evolved from the late Qing.

title: The Historical Anthropology of Chinese Society
requirements: For postgraduate students under Division of History and undergraduate History Major & Minor students
description: For a long time, historians and anthropologists have recognized that, despite its unity, Chinese society embodies regional social and cultural variations. To understand how Chinese society became a unity, it is necessary to trace the processes by which multiple rituals and customs converged so that they integrated with dynastic traditions. Those processes included the expansion of the imperial state from the Song dynasty to the Republic as well as the reactions of local societies to it. By combining field work and documentary analysis, this course sensitizes students to a history from below in which indigenous communities utilizes state rituals to express their own concerns and identities.
outcome: 1. To sensitise students to major concepts in the making of Chinese society.  2. To familiarize students with the combination of field experience and documentary research as an approach to   understanding Chinese history.  3. To contextualize major concepts in Chinese society to specific texts, images, architectural style, legends and rituals,  so that students may reconstruct the history behind their emergence and application. 4. To introduce students to the idea that “history” appears not only in words, but also through many other forms of   expression..  1 本課程從中國人習以為常的描述地方社會的概念開始，通過講解，讓學生明白這一類的概念是不同時期被發明和創造出來的傳統，有一個歷史過程。比如大家都有祖先，但是普通人能在祠堂祭祖並不是那麼久遠的事情，大致在明代中期以後。在中國許多地方，可能更為晚近。我們通過瞭解這個過程，探討地方社會如何利用禮儀來與國家互動等問題。 2 注重田野與文獻的結合。討論如何將書寫文獻與神明形象、建築形式、口述故事以及儀式展演等田野史料結合，進行研究。 3本課程希望在結束的時候，讓學生明白歷史並不是只有單一的敘述方式，而是有多重的聲音。希望能將歷史帶入他們的生活，也希望他們能尋找出活的歷史。

title: Patterns in Urban History and Development
requirements: For postgraduate students under Division of History and undergraduate History Major & Minor students
description: This module provides an introductory survey of the history of urban development from the ancient period to the end of the twentieth century. It focuses on the forces that have led to the development of cities in the past, and achieves this through the lens of a multi-disciplinary perspective and the utilisation of various methodologies. Such a standpoint is adopted in order to allow for the exploration of the impacts of matters like politics, economics, culture and identity, art and architecture, intellectual thought, law, transportation, and military technology upon urban society at different times in history, and to recognise how they influenced the design and shape of the built environment, and so city living. Central to the programme is the use of comparative analyses which assist in identifying and contrasting patterns of urban change. As such differences in urban design that became evident in the past will be made clear. Furthermore such an approach helps illuminate and clarify the imprint upon urban space and the urban mind of agents affecting the urban development process, including visions and concepts (built and unbuilt) that have swayed social development. Importantly too in utilising this analytical perspective students are granted opportunities to test hypotheses under the guidance of their teacher about the causes and effects of urban transition, in so doing helping explicitly comprehend the narrative of historical urban development in both factual and conceptual terms.
outcome: 1. To develop an understanding of the causes of urban development and the various agents that act upon cities (e.g. cultural, social, environmental, economic, legal, etc.) so as to expand already held knowledge about urban places across the world. 2. To recognise the relationship between the evolution of the design of urban settlements and the nature of societies. 3. To know how and why various contexts affect the shape and appearance of urban places within distinct historical periods. 4. To train to see and read urban places through the use of maps and various visual sources in order to recognise distinct architectural and urban design styles belonging to particular eras of the past. 5. To demonstrate historical knowledge via a small tutorial presentation.

title: China and The West
requirements: For postgraduate students under Division of History and undergraduate History Major & Minor students
description: This course studies the formation and transformation of late imperial Chinese diplomatic system. It examines how China established and maintained the tributary system, or the so-called Pax Sinica in East Asia from the 14th to the 19th century. It analyzes the complex process, starting in mid-19th century, in which China gradually accepted a new international order based on the assumption of nation-state and governed by Western international law.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will: •Have enhanced awareness and curiosity of the complex issue of cultural difference, political change, and international relationship in early modern East Asia; •Have enhanced sensitivity towards discourse, narratives, values and hidden agenda in historical records; •Have enhanced ability to practice the science and art of historical research; •Have enhanced reading, writing, and oral expression skills.  修讀本課程之後，學生將得到以下學習成果： *增加對於近代東亞的文化差異、政治變遷、國際關係的認識及興趣; *更準確和敏感地把握歷史檔案中的話語、敘述、價值及隱含之動機； *改善歷史研究這門科學和藝術的技藝； *改善閱讀、寫作、口頭表達與辯論的技巧。

title: Study of Emigrant Communities
requirements: For postgraduate students under Division of History and undergraduate History Major & Minor students
description: This course examines the interactive relations between the Chinese overseas and their hometowns from the 19th century. It attempts to investigate the factors that facilitate overseas migration, the changing perceptions of the Chinese overseas on their hometowns, their contributions towards the promotion or restriction of local modernization and the emigrant communities’ “overseas connections” as cultural capital in the shaping of local politics as well as social and economic lives. This course is divided into two parts. The first part, from a macro perspective, discusses the history of the Chinese overseas migration through an analysis of the business and migration environment and the social and economic foundations of the South China communities from the Ming Qing to the Republican period. The second part, from a micro perspective, examines selected emigrants communities, their social and cultural changes in relation to their overseas connections.
outcome: (1) As part of the Department’s public and comparative history curriculum, this course provides students with an alternative interpretation on the development of China and the Chinese overseas in the Modern period.  (2) Students will understand the foundation, operation, organization and changes of Chinese local societies and their interaction with the State and global communities from a cross-disciplinary perspective.  (3) Students are expected to construct their own analysis framework which, hopefully, could be applied into their daily activities.   (1）作為比較及公眾史學文學碩士課程的一部分，本課程提供學生一個明白近代中國和海外華僑華人的新的理解。 (2）學生可以從跨學科的視角，理解中國地方社會與國家及環球世界的互動關係的基礎、運作、組織和變遷。 （3）學生修畢本科，可以建立其自身的分析能力和框架，從而應用到日常生活之中。

Home-time connection: Interactive relations of migrants and their ancestral homeland 10. Politics and emigrant communities' overseas relation 11. Information and exchange: remittance, bulletins and magazines 12. Homeland imagination: construction of virtue lineage 13: Qiaoxiang (emigrant community) as cultural and social resources  1. 導論: 課題與討論  2. 華南僑鄉的歷史、社會與文化 3. 離鄉的宏觀環境: 16世紀以來中外交通 4. 海外移民的推拉力量； 18 及19世紀的華南: 以苦力貿易為中心 5. 皇朝觀點與海外移民：海盜、商人、苦力與契約勞工 6. 20世紀的華僑政策 7. 家庭、宗族與婦女：僑鄉的權力結構與聲音 8. 商業與投資：商業活動與網絡建構 9. 家鄉聯繫：移民與故鄉的互動關係 10. 僑鄉的政治與海外關係 11.資訊和交流：僑批、僑刊與鄉訊 12.家鄉的想像：虛擬宗族的建構 13.作為文化和社會資源的僑鄉
